We have seen a pronounced increase in ESG focus on the
gambling sector in the last year. We also note an increasing number of investor questions on our gambling coverage and their place in ESG screens. Press reports (e.g. Citywire, April 4, 2019) suggest a number of funds are reviewing their ability to retain positions in the sector. We believe that the sector is inherently a potential target of exclusionary criteria, as a traditional ‘sin’ sector.

11:21 am

BE11:22am

BE11:22am

Anyway:

Soundbuy Sloth is underrated
11:22 am
BE11:22am

We cut our target multiples for gambling stocks by c.15%, believing the industry has entered a new reality where multiples will be fundamentally lower, amid persisting regulatory uncertainty and maturing levels of growth. Although the sector now trades at a material discount to average multiples over 2015-18, looking over the last 15 years reveals that valuations have largely returned to the longer-term average multiple of c.10x for a similar headline growth outlook. Multiples climbed between 2015 and early 2018 as asset-light, online-driven growth accelerated alongside material consolidation in the UK and a (relatively) stable regulatory environment in mature markets. But now, we are seeing a rising regulatory burden on the industry, which we believe is here to stay and, combined with greater market maturity, will lead to a normalisation of the growth outlook for the sector. Moreover, with growing focus on ESG-integration, we think online gaming companies’ multiple could remain depressed, even if growth opportunities arise, unless they are able to more clearly demonstrate to investors that they are actively engaging with key ESG issues facing the sector. We note European disclosure on key ESG issues related to gaming tends to lag that of global peers.

BE11:22am

We still expect our gaming companies to deliver a greater than 7% 5-year EBITDA CAGR on average. While some mature markets might come under pressure from a slower macro, we see the outlook supported by structural migration online and new gambling verticals opening. Further, the sector still provides structurally attractive investment opportunities, in our view, given cyclical pressures on other parts of the leisure sector. We prefer diversified, scale players with strong cash generation to fund expansion. We reiterate our Buys on TSG/GVC, while Neutral-rated PPB’s US opportunity appears priced in. We remain cautious on Neutral-rated WMH (execution risk scaling down its retail business/leverage profile). We deep dive into the early trends of NJ sports betting market, and with our detailed state models we expect online sports betting in NJ to cross $0.5bn in two years, with 28% of the total market online by 2021 GSe.

BE11:30am

Citi take – Management is flagging that the UK re-underwriting is on track and that Q1 large losses/ weather experience was as expected. Modest losses on exit portfolios are now also expected with further detail to be given in 2019. Meanwhile, flagged reserve strengthening on the 2018 year will raise questions and solvency was weaker than our expectation. FX and lower investment yields will also drag on earnings in 2019/ 20. Overall still plenty to prove with the UK turnaround and we think this takes time to deliver at time when other headwinds are building.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Q1 trading update – GWP was flat on an underlying basis and in line with
management plan. This included a 5% reduction in the UK due to re-underwriting actions offset by 8% growth in Canada as the market hardens and RSA grows in personal lines. Q1 weather losses of 3.2% of NEP and large losses of 8.5% were both broadly consistent with 5-year averages, with the attritional loss ratio slightly better y-o-y (as we expected). Q1 prior year reserve development is indicated to be flat vs FY but with some cautious comments around the need to strengthen on the 2018 year. The Solvency II ratio was 164% which compared with our estimate of 169%.

BE11:31am

Questions for the call – The call is at 8.30am. Key questions: a) what is behind the 2018 PYD reserve strengthening, b) 2019 expected booked losses on exit portfolios, c) drivers of the change in the S2 ratio since year end, d) outlook for UK and total premium growth for full year.
Implications – There are new concerns on the 2018 underwriting year and
expected losses on exit portfolios need quantification. The Solvency miss is also unhelpful. While management is reassuring on the turnaround, we see today's update marginally negative for the shares.

BE11:31am

And UBS.

red i think liverpools takes the top slot as it was vs a long time quality side. ajax not in that class.
11:31 am
BE11:31am

A: Overall: we see this as a miss vs. our expectations on 1Q19 profit commentary, but we sense 2019E consensus is still underpinned. On most underwriting metrics (premium, large losses, weather and attritional) commentary is in-line to slightly better than expected, but there is reserve strengthening which we weren't expecting, and the FX drag is worse. Detail: Premiums: NWP grew +3% in reported terms, and was flat underlying (in-line), driven by Scandinavia +3% (UBSe: +1%), Canada +8% (UBSe: +8.5%) and UK -5% (UBSe: -5%). Profitability: RSA notes operating profit for 1Q19 was up vs. 1Q18 at constant FX, but flat in reported terms, with an improving COR offset by lower investment income. For 1H19E, we forecast £341m of operating profit vs. £304m in 1H18, so this looks weaker vs. our estimates. RSA reported 3.2% of weather (UBSe: 3.3%), with Canada elevated and UK / Scandi benign as expected. Large losses were 8.5ppt (UBSe: 9.5%), driven by better UK. Reserve releases look to be ~0% (UBSe: 1.5%) driven by some strengthening on 2018; this looks to be the main driver of the miss vs. our estimates. RSA notes the attritional improved slightly in the quarter, as expected. The Solvency II ratio of 164% was weaker (we sense consensus at ~167%) driven by impact of falling Gilts on the pension scheme.

BE11:32am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: We highlight: 1) Reserve strengthening on 2018 and FX the main negative delta: we note there has been some loss creep reported at peers, but we had hoped RSA was underweight these areas. A miss on reserve releases looks to be the main negative vs. our expectations on the underwriting side. At the Group level, FX headwinds are also a little worse (3% headwind to 1Q19 EPS). 2) This result looks weaker vs. UBSe, but we still see FY19 consensus as underpinned: Our 2019E PBT estimate is ~6% ahead of consensus. 1Q19 is tracking behind our estimates mainly driven by reserve strengthening (assume non-recurring) and FX, but our early read of this result suggests no need to change 2Q19-4Q19E estimates beyond the FX drag. Our sense is that FY19E consensus is still largely underpinned.
Q: Any change to guidance?
A: No change to guidance.
Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: We expect a small negative reaction on the reserve strengthening and Solvency miss, tempered by our view that consensus does not need to fall.

Ultimately, we think it is too early to see the impact of the underwriting
actions and new reinsurance programmes that were announced at FY18
in response to the losses from last year. It was noted however, that the
underwriting actions are on track and that additional disclosures will be
provided for the exit portfolios in 2019. We expect that the benefits from
these actions will emerge gradually as premium is earned over the next
year or so. Based on the London Market result in the last three years, we
believe the UK&I combined ratio would have improved by about 2.3ppts
on average, had RSA not written the business that it intends to exit.
We also would not expect to see any material recoveries from the new
reinsurance programmes purchased at this stage of the year, as they are
bought to cover losses for an entire year.

Record numbers of Americans are stressed, worried and angry according to Gallop's latest annual update on the world's emotional state. This is occurring even as the US economy breaks the record for the longest economic cycle and with one of the lowest unemployment rates in history! How can this be? Maybe like me they are so angry with the recent statements from the Fed, intent on taking yet another giant step in their quest to find new excuses for their easier and ultimately ruinous monetary policy.

I don't know about you but I find the results of the Gallop Survey on the world's emotional state shocking. When asked about people's feelings, the majority of Americans (55%) said they had experienced stress during a lot of the day, nearly half (45%) said they felt worried a lot, and more than one in five (22%) said they felt anger a lot. Each of these figures matches or tops previous highs in the US.

And I don't think that's just due to my genetic disposition to be angry - Gallop reports Armenia is the angriest country in the world with a full 45% surveyed expressing a lot of anger recently, compared to the paltry 22% of angry Americans! Why am I so angry? It's the latest monetary pirouettes coming out of the Fed. Not content with their recent bizarre U-turn on rate hikes and QT, they have without much fanfare begun introducing a major policy shift towards structurally easier monetary policy via average inflation targeting. We've been here before and know this will end badly.

Ahead of the proposed tariff increase at midnight on Friday, rhetoric from the US is heating up. Trump has placed the blame on China saying that they “broke” the deal amid allegations of China backtracking on previously agreed provisions. China is predictably threatening retaliation.
 The market is growing increasingly concerned that trade negotiations can devolve into a no-deal scenario. We shouldn’t be overly surprised of Trump’s hardball negotiating tactics; there is still room for compromise, but the chance of a resolution is clearly more tenuous than before.
 What happens to asset prices beyond this week is decidedly contingent on (i) if tariffs are raised on Friday and (ii) if they are, what is the messaging from each side (i.e. will they further discussions to find common ground or will there be a complete breakdown in negotiations).

red @GBKronalets just say if we get a bunch of +ve tweets from him, over next 48 hours, will anyone be suprised.
11:40 am
BE11:41am

 For the time being, the USD continues its ascent against Asian currencies. There have been substantial moves in the past month (for instance, USD-CNH has traced 50% of its move in 2019).
 Despite the ferocity of dollar appreciation, it doesn’t seem like investors have a lot of risk on, suggesting that if trade war news flows does not improve this weekend there are further losses in store for Asia FX. We continue to recommend long USD-TWD, long USD-THB, short KRW against SGD, JPY, and USD, long USD-INR via risk reversals and long USD-IDR via a 3x12 steepener.
 Our forecasts have assumed USD-CNH rising toward 6.95 by year-end, but not breaching 7.0 until Q1 2020. This was predicated on trade negotiations continuing. If the two sides walk away, the chance of USD-CNY breaking 7.0 earlier than we expected would increase. However, we still aren’t worried about a much larger / tail-risk depreciation scenario given the CCF and capital flow management policies means that the RMB falls only as much, and as fast, as the authorities want.

BE11:43am

We remain cautiously optimistic of a US-China trade deal in 2Q-19 — The
renewed tariff threat by President Trump is likely being used as part of a negotiation strategy to cement concessions from China, amid reports of China reneging from these. As negotiations are in the final stage, the US is raising the stakes to close a deal or have no deal at all (for now), in-line with our base-case.
 But the opportunity window for avoiding a trade war is closing fast — We remain of the view that if we do not see a trade deal in 2Q, the relative growth dynamics between the US and China in 2H-19 suggest that the US leverage will not be as great as it is now, unless it goes to a trade war. While the US may be more sensitive to a trade war by then, we continue to believe that the larger share of the cost is likely to be borne by China and spillovers to the rest of the world.
 We currently assign a 40% probability that tariffs increase on Friday and that trade tensions escalate — The timeline for a ‘Trade War Today, Trade Deal Tomorrow’ would depend on how fast China comes back to the table (as soon as in a few days or extending into 2020 or beyond). The initial increase in tariffs is likely to trigger Chinese retaliation, but as the uncertainty effect from the additional tariffs
starts weighing on the Chinese economy, we expect China to look for resuming trade talks before additional tariffs are actually implemented (which could be as soon as early/mid-July).

BE11:43am

 Trade war impact is likely to be larger than what we have seen so far — The impact of the tariffs increase on the $200bn list would lower Chinese growth by ~0.5pp and global growth by 0.2ppover the next 1-2 years. But tariffs on all Chinese imports could have more than twice the impact on growth. The effect on inflation has been modest thus far, in particular because 60% of consumer goods imported from China have not received a tariff yet. As the trade war impact spillovers through the rest of the world, additional central banks easing is likely to follow.
 How have markets reacted to previous tariffs? — As markets brace for a USChina trade war, we review how asset prices have performed around the previous announcements on US tariffs on Chinese imports; as well how equities/exchange rates moved the most after the tariffs announcements across a range of economies.
We note that US 10yr bond yields on average declined for about a week before resuming an upward move, US equities on average increase for at least a week. Equities and exchange rates from Asian economies and commodity exporters were the worst performers, on average, after an announcement

The Works’ trading has slowed in Q4, largely down to external factors, but we must downgrade outer year numbers. The warm Easter weather has meant that footfall to stores has been weak and the lack of a “mega-trend” hasn’t helped either. Online sales remain healthy, with a particular strength in Click and Collect, but with the exit rate of LFL being zero, it’s hard to be bullish about the year just beginning. The downgrades aren’t big (£0.5m), but it is a dent to short-term momentum and the shares are likely to reflect that for a while (TP from 170p to 135p), even if the fundamentals of the business remain very positive.

BE11:55am

Today’s FY trading update shows there has been a slowdown towards year end impacted by the general weak consumer environment, with Easter, we suspect, suffering from the hot weather. In-line with management guidance, we downgrade FY19e PBT by 8%. While a downgrade is disappointing, the attractive long term roll-out story is still intact and not reflected in valuation, we believe.
New stores continue to achieve attractive paybacks. BUY reiterated.
 FY trading update shows a slowdown in LFL growth in the final quarter,
impacted by a weak industry trading environment generally and a reasonably tough YoY comparable helped by slime. There are no Mega Trends currently. Also, BRC data points to volatile sales and a difficult Easter with the hot weather hitting footfall. FY sales were up 13.2%, with LFL up 3%. After reporting 1H19 LFL +3.8% and 1st 11 weeks 2H +4.5%, this mathematically implies flat LFL for the remainder of the year.
 New stores continue to deliver particularly strong paybacks (last said 13
months), according to management, helped by a favourable property market and disciplined site selection. 50 new stores were opened in FY19 taking the total estate to 497 stores. Management confirms a strong pipeline and expects to open a net 50 in FY20.
 FY19e/FY20e PBT downgrades by 8%/5% respectively to reflect 2% lower FY19 sales growth versus our forecast. Management is guiding adjusted FY19 PBT to be around the bottom end of consensus expectations, which is £7.4m. FY20e is downgraded due to the lower base with no change to growth
expectations. While it will be up against Squishies Mega Trend in 1H (started May), 2H is likely to benefit from product associated with a strong kids films pipeline, such as Frozen, and non-repeat of last year’s Christmas online fulfilment issues.
 Valuation looks undemanding (CY20e PE 8.7x, FCF yield 7.6%) for a
sustainable 10-11 year roll-out story. Management remains confident of its 1,000 store target and we continue to believe WRKS fills a niche on the High Street for a family friendly value proposition. Our TP falls to 200p (prev 210p), reflecting the downgrade, but we reiterate Buy

BE11:59am

Q1 19 adjusted EBITDA ahead of estimates
In its trading update, Mondi reported Q1 19 adjusted EBITDA of €471m, which was ahead of our expectation of €398m (no consensus available), but mainly driven by deviations in timing effects of pricing (limited containerboard price erosion q-o-q) and maintenance costs (only €15m vs. 90m H1); we assume Q2 19 EBITDA will trade down. Divergence in price trends across key grades
Since the peak late-2018, containerboard prices have steadily eroded in Europe, with FOEX PIX kraftliner prices so far down by 11% and testliner by 15%, driven by weak demand, increasing inventories in the value chain and low-priced imports from the US.
The knock-on effect on corrugated board has so far been marginal, but the pressure is building. On the other hand, uncoated fine paper prices have held up surprisingly well despite pulp prices turning down, with FOEX PIX prices still showing a modest 1% increase year-to-date. Also, sack kraft papers have stabilised at a high level (2019 German spot price up 4-6% vs. 2018 average assuming stable prices going forward), with downstream industrial bags passing through the paper price increases On balance overall stable earnings outlook for 2019
On aggregate, and considering the earnings outlook for 2019, we believe price pressure has increased a bit, especially due to continued declines in containerboard prices. Also, cost inflation is running at c2% and Mondi will have c€40m more in maintenance costs this year. However, there are also mitigating factors: acquisitions (Powerflute) should add some €30-40m y-o-y, and benefits from growth projects (Steti) c€60m. Consensus EBITDA currently stands at €1.76bn (flat y-o-y).
Valuation: Buy; we update PT to reflect Plc and FX
Mondi had a strong start to the year, but the price outlook is mixed and current trends, especially in containerboard pricing, bring some uncertainty to estimates. We intend to review our assumptions, which currently factor in 8-9% lower kraftliner/testliner prices n 2019 y-o-y in Europe vs. current spot prices in Germany (reference market) implying 11-13%, which would indicate downside risk of c3% to EBITDA (assuming no further price erosion). Despite short-term headwinds, we think Mondi remains well positioned longer term with its low-cost asset base and growth investments supporting margins and returns.

Mondi consistently generates high returns and strong cash flow.

growth. With improving pricing dynamics and stable costs, our full
year profit and cash flow forecasts look secure. Mondi’s share
price has risen by 5% year-to-date, underperforming the sector. At

reiterate our ‘Outperform’ rating.

BE12:00pm

Mondi Group issued a Q1 trading update for the three months to end-March. Underlying EBITDA for the period was €471m, up 16% from the €405m reported in the same period last year. Lower year-on-year (yoy) maintenance costs (€20m) and the impact of acquisitions (€10-15m) contributed to the strong performance.
Stripping these out implies organic EBITDA growth in the period of circa 8-10% – similar to the 11% organic growth reported by Smurfit Kappa Group last week. Sales volumes were marginally lower in the period while average prices were higher yoy but flat sequentially. In the Fibre Packaging division, which accounts for over 60% of profits, higher sack kraft prices offset lower containerboard prices. Corrugated volumes were higher, offset by weaker volumes of industrials bags. While most costs were higher, the exception was OCC which was down 24% yoy. Profits in the Consumer Packaging division (10% of profits) continued to improve, while higher prices in Uncoated Fine Paper (30% of profts) offset lower volumes and higher costs.

BE12:01pm

On the conference call, the overall sense was that pricing dynamics are
improving. On sack kraft, while industrial demand was lower in Q1, demand from consumer usage (20% of volumes) is growing strongly. The outlook for mid-year price negotiations therefore is positive. On containerboard, the outlook for kraftliner pricing has improved since the start of the year. Order books have picked up and containerboard inventories, while still slightly high, continue to decline. The CEO is now less bearish on the prospects for pricing. Corrugated prices will likely reflect the recent declines in containerboard prices, although the lag may be “longer than usual”. There are no signs of any increase in OCC prices, with some evidence that China is importing more containerboard to replace lower OCC volumes.
For H1, we are forecasting EBITDA for the group of €866m, 2% ahead of H1 2018. Full year profits are forecast to fall by 4% as a result of the decline in containerboard and corrugated prices in the second half of the year. We see no reason to amend these forecasts for now.

BE12:02pm

Mondi reported Q1 19 EBITDA growth of 16% to EUR471m – better than the mid single digit growth we thought would be achieved in our preview; and with Mondi trading on 10.4x FY19e PE on Wed’s close, probably better than the market expected. Clearly however ongoing macro events (trade war volatility and weak activity data from key regions) will have a significant impact on valuations beyond historical reported performance.
Key drivers of performance were higher average prices (Mondi’s mix includes many grades outside of unbleached kraftliner, which had rising/stable prices in Q1), Powerflute & project contribution and lower planned maintenance shuts (ex this growth would’ve been 11%). Maintenance shut costs are expected to have a
significant impact in Q2 (EUR75m vs EUR20m in the prior year). Cash flow remains strong with operating cash flow positive despite ongoing project capex. Industrial bag volume decline YoY is of some concern with regard to how this may affect kraft paper prices but Mondi commentary suggests no obvious downward trend in downstream demand. Box volumes are growing and commentary on prices was positive (still trending up) however we would ultimately expect pricing pressure in an environment of declining containerboard prices.
Consumer packaging performance was encouraging in terms of YoY progress. The effective lowering of ROCE
target in this segment is negative but we doubt the market was building in expectations of this anyway (we certainly weren’t). Outlook commentary was largely positive in our view given what are clearly more difficult commodity markets YoY. Box volumes are still growing and Mondi has suggested risks of further containerboard price declines are closer to “50/50” rather than “90/10” previously (we would estimate current valuation implies further 5-10% declines vs Apr spot). Kraft paper prices remain stable in spot markets according to Mondi. Cost inflation is expected to remain modest (1-2% cost inflation expected at this juncture).

BE12:02pm

This set of results points to some positive signs and Mondi’s valuation suggests more downside in the price already however we would still expect an improvement in the macro will be required to drive any momentum in the stock.

BE12:14pm

1. Higher mid-term capex: The current capex supports build out of fibre to 1mn homes annually. However, BT's ambition to reaching 15m homes by March 2026 (1.2mn currently) would require an accelerated annual run-rate of c2mn homes passed. Whilst there will be opportunities to reduce capex in some areas (emergency services network, VDSL tail off, more energy efficiency), we believe capex will inevitably have to increase from the near-term guidance of £3.8bn pa.
2. Too early for BT to revise the dividend policy: How BT decides to fund the higher capex will a "matter for the Board at the right time". BT said "things can always change". If BT were to approve the business case to reach 15mn homes with fibre, then the Board will consider how to fund this investment. There are also other alternatives to cutting the dividend, such as increase borrowing, more opex benefits and re-allocating its capex deployment.
3. Openreach spinoff? "no we are not looking at this at all", said the CEO: At the heart of BT is the network, said management. Openreach is a strategic asset and having the BT retail as an anchor tenant is very important to them (gives certainty when Openreach make big investments). On monetising mobile towers, BT remind that most of the mobile infrastructure is already shared, so they see only limited opportunities in specific areas.
4. Telco competition has stepped up in the last 6 months due to regulation, technology and new entrants. Consumer fixed revenues declined by -3% YoY (also annualising a tough comp), whilst postpaid mobile revenues also slowed to +1.5% from previous quarters of c+3%
5. TV content investments into sports have been successful, according to BT. However, BT will not expand on its Sports offering. The next major rights auction is the UEFA rights, where BT currently pay c£400mn pa.
